But two obligations are essential; is there is not one to novate, the attempted novation is null ; il there is one to novate, but the novating contract is void (eg. ‘si id quod tu mihi debeas, a peregrino, cum quo sponsus communio non est, spondes verbo stipulatus sim' Gaius iii. 179), the former is altogether unaliected.

The promise of a slave ordinarily created a natural obligation, and consequently‚ as Servius Sulpicius argued (Gaius, loc. cit), it is hard to see why it should have no novative ellect; the explanation given by Theophilus is ὅτι ποιεῖ νοβατίωνα οὗ μόνον τὸ τίκτεσθαι φυσικὴν ε’νοχήν, ἀλλὰ καὶ τὸ ὑπεῖναι πρόσωπον· ἇπρόσωποε δὲ ὁ δοῦλος.

The rule that, if the parties to the new contract are the same, a novation ensues only is it contains ‘novi quid,' holds only where the novated obligation was itself verbal. tf it had been otherwise, novation would have been disabled from discharging one ol its most valued functione, viz. the substitution of obligations pursued by actions stricti iuris sor obligations enlorceable only by actio ex fide bona. The Procu- lians were os opinion that the adiectio or detractio oi a surety in the new contract was not sufficient to support a novation, Gaius iii. 178.

For condicio and dies see on Tit. 15. 2 and 4 supr.

Servius Sulpicius had held that a conditional stipulation novated an unconditional contract whether the condition was fulfilled or not. Gaius (iii. 179) thought that the old contract subsisted until the condition ol the new one was fulfilled, but suggests that it the creditor sued upon it before such lulfilment he might be met by exceptio doli or pacti, and this was soon recognised as law, Dig. 23. 3. 50; ib. 83; 12.· 1. 36 ; though Labeo (Dig. 2 3. 3. 80) had thought otherwise.

Among the praesumptiones or evidence upon which the jurists relied to prove that there was animus novandi was, according to the Sabinian school, the addition ol asurety (cf. Dig. 2. 14. 30. 1) ; sor the presumptione against such intention see Dig. 46. 2. 6. pr. and 1. ; 45. 1. 58. Justinian’s own enactment is in Cod. 8. 42· 8 ; his statement that, unless the interi· tion to novate was express (‘ nisi ipsi specialiter remiserint quidem priorem obligationem et hoc expresserint, quod secundam magis pro anterioribus elegerint' Cod. loc cit), the two obligations should subsist side by side is apparently subject to the qualification that when one was tulfilted the other was ipso facto extinguished; see Dig. 46. 2. 8. 5.
